speaker: Agent
text: NovaNet technical support, this is Joshua. Are you calling about internet issues today?

speaker: Customer
text: Yes. It keeps dropping like every hour. I’m working from home and it’s driving me insane.

speaker: Agent
text: I’m with you. Let’s get it stable. First, I’ll verify the account—name and service address?

speaker: Customer
text: Nitin Verma, 301, Skyview Heights, Gurgaon.

speaker: Agent
text: Thanks. I see your Fiber 400 line. Now, when it drops—do you lose Wi-Fi only, or does the whole internet go down? Like, do wired devices also drop, if you have any?

speaker: Customer
text: Mostly Wi-Fi. My laptop shows connected but no internet.

speaker: Agent
text: That’s an important clue. If Wi-Fi stays connected but internet dies, it could be the router losing upstream connection, or DNS issues, or the fiber link flapping. Let’s check your router and ONT lights. Are you near the devices right now?

speaker: Customer
text: Yeah I’m next to them.

speaker: Agent
text: Great. Please tell me the lights you see on the ONT box—Power, PON/Optical, LOS, and LAN—what are they doing?

speaker: Customer
text: Power is green. PON is green. LOS is off. LAN is blinking.

speaker: Agent
text: That actually looks healthy on the fiber side—PON green and LOS off means the optical link is stable. So we likely focus on router/Wi-Fi. Which router model do you have—any label like NovaWave AX1800?

speaker: Customer
text: Yeah, NovaWave AX1800.

speaker: Agent
text: Perfect. Next: how many devices are typically connected? Phones, TVs, laptops, smart stuff—ballpark.

speaker: Customer
text: Like… 12? Maybe more. Two TVs, two laptops, phones, Alexa, all that.

speaker: Agent
text: Okay, that’s normal household density. Intermittent Wi-Fi drops can happen if the 2.4 GHz band is congested, or if the router is overheating, or if a device is hogging bandwidth with backups. Let’s run two checks: (1) restart the router cleanly, and (2) run a speed test on a single device close to the router.

speaker: Customer
text: I already restarted before.

speaker: Agent
text: Totally—most people do. The difference is we’ll do a ‘full power cycle’ in the correct order so the ONT and router renegotiate cleanly. Steps: unplug router power. Wait 10 seconds. Then unplug ONT power. Wait 30 seconds. Then plug ONT back in, wait until PON is solid green, then plug router back in.

speaker: Customer
text: Okay, doing it.

speaker: Customer
text: Router unplugged.

speaker: Customer
text: ONT unplugged.

speaker: Agent
text: Cool. While we wait the 30 seconds, quick question: is the router placed in a closed cabinet or near heat sources? Overheating can cause periodic resets.

speaker: Customer
text: It’s in the TV unit shelf. Kinda enclosed.

speaker: Agent
text: That could be a real culprit. Wi-Fi routers are tiny space heaters with feelings. They need airflow. After we stabilize things, I’ll recommend moving it into open air if possible.

speaker: Customer
text: Okay, ONT back in.

speaker: Agent
text: Wait for PON solid green…

speaker: Customer
text: It’s green now.

speaker: Agent
text: Great. Plug the router back in.

speaker: Customer
text: Done.

speaker: Agent
text: Give it about 60 seconds. While it boots, do you see any red light on the router?

speaker: Customer
text: No, normal.

speaker: Agent
text: Now on your phone or laptop, connect to your 5 GHz Wi-Fi network—usually it’s the one with ‘_5G’ suffix. Are you connected to 5 GHz or 2.4?

speaker: Customer
text: I’m on the normal one. Not sure which.

speaker: Agent
text: No worries. On most phones, if you tap the Wi-Fi network details, it shows frequency. If it’s 5 GHz, it’s typically faster and less congested but shorter range. If it’s 2.4, it’s longer range but crowded. Can you check?

speaker: Customer
text: It says 2.4.

speaker: Agent
text: Let’s switch to 5 GHz for your work laptop if it’s nearby. Pick the ‘_5G’ network and enter the same password.

speaker: Customer
text: Okay… connected.

speaker: Agent
text: Great. Now open a speed test site—any is fine—and run it once. Tell me download, upload, and ping.

speaker: Customer
text: Download 280 Mbps, upload 310, ping 6.

speaker: Agent
text: That’s excellent. So the line is strong right now. The drop issue might be Wi-Fi interference or router stability. Let’s check router uptime logs on my side—NovaWave supports remote diagnostics if enabled. I see it is enabled.

speaker: Agent
text: I’m looking at the last 24 hours: router reboot events at 11:02 AM, 1:14 PM, 3:09 PM, and 5:05 PM. That pattern looks like overheating or a power fluctuation.

speaker: Customer
text: So it’s the router?

speaker: Agent
text: Very likely. Two action items: (1) Move router to open air and keep it upright, not stacked under devices. (2) If possible, plug it into a surge protector. Also, we can push a firmware update if yours is behind.

speaker: Customer
text: Do the update.

speaker: Agent
text: Okay. Firmware push will briefly restart Wi-Fi for about 2 minutes. Do you want me to do it now or later tonight?

speaker: Customer
text: Now. I’ll survive.

speaker: Agent
text: Alright, initiating update…

speaker: Agent
text: Wi-Fi may drop—this is expected.

speaker: Customer
text: Yeah it disconnected.

speaker: Agent
text: Good sign actually—it’s applying. Give it another minute.

speaker: Customer
text: It’s back.

speaker: Agent
text: Awesome. I now see firmware version updated. Next: I’ll also optimize Wi-Fi channels. I’m setting 2.4 GHz to auto channel selection and reducing band steering aggressiveness, which helps stability for mixed devices.

speaker: Customer
text: Okay.

speaker: Agent
text: Now, if the drops continue after moving the router out of the cabinet, we should replace the router. I can create a dispatch ticket, but I’d rather not waste your time if placement fixes it.

speaker: Customer
text: I can move it now.

speaker: Agent
text: Do it—just ensure it’s at least a hand’s width away from walls and not enclosed.

speaker: Customer
text: Okay moved.

speaker: Agent
text: Perfect. Let’s monitor. I’ll set a 48-hour ‘stability watch’ on the line, which flags if the router reboots again. If it does, we’ll replace it without arguing.

speaker: Customer
text: Good.

speaker: Agent
text: Recap: fiber link looks stable, router was rebooting multiple times, firmware updated, channels optimized, router moved to open air. If you still get drops, call us and reference case TS-884210 so you don’t have to repeat the whole saga.

speaker: Customer
text: Thanks.

speaker: Agent
text: You got it. May your Wi-Fi behave like a civilized network. Take care.
